The Buddha said: When a practitioner of the Way gives rise to an angry mind, they should restrain themselves. Restraining
and thinking of goodness is the practice of a practitioner of the Way.

If one gives away wealth and benefits, and upon obtaining them, considers them impermanent, and does not commit offenses with the body, namely, not committing killing, stealing, or sexual misconduct, this is not committing offenses with the body.
One who has overcome anger does not speak with the mouth or think with the mind, this is overcoming the mind of anger. The greatest sound in the mind is
like a person who commits theft and says:
'What you have done is extremely shameless.'
This is the greatest sound in the mind.
The Buddha said:
As for the sequence of tastes, when eating food, externally combine it, and internally distinguish its flavors without error. This is the sequence of tastes.

The reason why the Bodhisattva was able to know this is because in his past lives, whenever he ate, he would first offer to his parents and spiritual practitioners before eating himself. This is why he attained the thirty-two marks and eighty minor characteristics.
The Buddha said:
The Bodhisattva, through four practices, attains the four forms of fearlessness:
First, he himself knows and also wishes to make others know;
Second, he teaches without weariness;
Third, he has an impartial mind and conceals nothing;
Fourth, he explains the sutras to others without regret afterwards;
These are the four practices.
The Buddha, through four practices, also attains the four forms of fearlessness:
First, he speaks in accordance with the Dharma;
Second, he does not accept offerings from others;
Third, he has an impartial mind;
Fourth, he is fully endowed with precepts.
The Buddha said:
There are also four forms of fearlessness:
First, he speaks in accordance with the facts;
Second, he has nothing to be stingy about;
Third, he has spiritual powers;
Fourth, not to dispute with others.
The Buddha's light from the top of his head has three causes and conditions:
First, offering lamps to the Buddha's temple;
Second, delighting in the scriptures;
Third, resolving others' doubts and bonds.
The Buddha raising his right hand has four causes and conditions:
First, because evil people are ungrateful;
Second, because good people are grateful;
Third, demonstrating the teachings;
Fourth, telling people not to do evil.
The Buddha raising his right hand has four more causes and conditions:
First, wanting to cause people in the ten directions to come and study the path according to their intentions;
Second, wanting to show people that the blessings I have practiced have now resulted in these marks;
Third, encouraging people to all uphold the precepts;
Fourth, the demeanor is naturally like this, and also not wanting to see people's bad temperaments, therefore raising the right hand in all cases.
There are three reasons why the Buddha does not wear shoes:
First, to make practitioners have few desires;
Second, to reveal the wheel on the soles of his feet;
Third, to make people who see it rejoice.
When the Buddha walks, his feet are four inches above the ground, for three reasons:
First, because he sees there are insects and ants on the ground;
Second, because there are living plants on the ground;
Third, to manifest his spiritual powers, and also to make people's minds rest on the Buddha's walking.
When the Buddha walks, the high and low places on the ground all become level, for three reasons:

First, because he originally practiced the four immeasurable minds, wishing to make everyone peaceful and secure. The earth is on the water, and there are spirits in the water. Insects and ants all encounter the Buddha's feet, and they are all at peace and stand with the same intention. Therefore, the low becomes high, and the high becomes low;
Second, the gods and spirits practice blessings and remove the ground for the Buddha, so the high and low become level;

Third, when the Buddha was a bodhisattva, he used the path of thorough understanding to build bridges and ferry people across. Because of this, he attained blessings. Therefore, the ground is high and low, but level, wanting to make people's minds also like this.
The Buddha does not fly, for four reasons:
First, he encourages his disciples to be diligent;
Second, he wants his disciples to listen to the sutras;
Third, he repays the kindness of his past lives;
Fourth, he manifests signs, and therefore does not fly.

When the Buddha was in the world, the devas, ghosts, dragons, and people all came to where the Buddha was to listen to the sutras. Thousands and hundreds of layers, walking and sitting in front and back, all saw the Buddha's face.
Why is this?

Because in the Buddha's past life, his words had no front or back, and therefore there was no one who did not see the Buddha's face. When people lay down, they all followed the Buddha's head, because the Buddha was revered.
The Buddha did not eat for seven days after first attaining enlightenment, for four reasons:
First, he forgot to eat while contemplating the Way;
Second, the mind is not hungry;
Third, being joyful, one is not thirsty;
Fourth, not thinking of pain, itching, thoughts, birth and death, and consciousness;
These are the four.
One should listen to the sutra in the same way.
The Buddha's kasaya does not attract dust or water, and external dirt does not stick to it, for two reasons:
First, because he does not think of the evil of all people;
Second, because he sees that all people have desires and wishes to eliminate them.
The Buddha washes the kasaya again because external dirt does not stick to it but internal dirt does, because he has a body and therefore has dirt.
Why is this?

Because external practice has already been exhausted, dirt does not stick to the outside, but internal practice has not yet been exhausted, so dirt sticks to the inside. Because of having a body, the inside is not yet exhausted. Using the body as a means of committing offenses, therefore he does not cherish his body and life.
Why is this?
He cherishes life because life can attain the Way.
The Buddha spoke the Sutra of Eighty Million Causes and Conditions, which comprehensively treats people's three illnesses:
First, greed and lust;
Second, anger and hatred;
Third, ignorance and foolishness.
These three things are divided into six, so they correspond to the six declines to treat the three illnesses.
The reason the sutra has many is like a person taking medicine whose illness does not heal, they should take other medicine.
The Buddha said:
'People's minds have many aspects and turn quickly, so there are many sutras to treat them according to their minds, wanting to make them quickly understand.'
The Buddha had already attained the Way, but still had three illnesses and six worries.
The six worries are the worries about the six sense entrances, and the three illnesses are the mind, consciousness, and sense perception.

The Buddha, having already attained the Way, still had these worries and illnesses, let alone other people whose calamities and offenses are not yet finished and who cannot transcend the world, or whose Buddha-work is not yet complete and who cannot transcend the world.
The Buddha abandoned the remaining twenty years of his life for three reasons:
First, because worldly people are greedy for the body;
Second, the teachings have been fully imparted;
Third, fearing that evil people will slander and incur grave offenses, they will then attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
When the Buddha passes away, he does not take the body with him, nor does he take the mind with him, but simply the cessation of suffering.
Earth, water, fire, wind, and space are always present in the world without interruption.
There are three reasons why the Buddha's body is cremated after his passing:
First, because it will rot;
Second, because insects and moths will be born from it;
Third, because people can gain merit by bringing incense and flowers as offerings.
When the Buddha smiles, five-colored lights emerge from his mouth for five reasons:
First, he wants to encourage people to ask questions, as there will be benefits from the questions asked;
Second, he fears people will say the Buddha does not know how to smile;
Third, he manifests the light from his mouth;
Fourth, he smiles at those who are not sincere;
Fifth, he smiles at arhats who guard emptiness and do not attain the bodhisattva path.
The light returning and entering from the crown indicates that he will later greatly illuminate the world.

Now that the Buddha has transcended the world, from whom will the people of the world obtain blessings?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Although I have transcended the world, the scriptures and teachings will remain.
There are four causes and conditions by which blessings can be obtained:
First, if animals have nothing to eat, feed them to sustain their lives;
Second, if one sees people who are sick and have no one to care for them, provide them with offerings to ensure their well-being;
Third, protect and care for the poor and the orphaned;
Fourth, if a person practices meditation and contemplates the Way alone, without clothing or food, provide for them;
These are the four things.
Generously give with a wholesome mind, and the blessings obtained are equal to those of the Buddha, without distinction.
At that time, my whole body ached, and I wanted to leave the world.

After the Buddha passed away, the arhats jointly reprimanded Ä€nanda:
When the Buddha was in the world and wanted water, why didn't you give it to him?

Even if he abides for an eon in the world, how could Maitreya come down and become a Buddha?
Among those who originally practiced the Way together with the Buddha, there were 80 million people, all seeking the bodhisattva path. Only two people attained the Way:
First, ÅšÄkyamuni;

The Buddha's forbearance surpasses the earth, his mind is softer than water, his intention is firmer than Mount Sumeru, his merits surpass the waters of the ocean, and his wisdom surpasses space. For this reason, he attained Buddhahood first.
The Buddha said:
There are four reasons why Maitreya will not come down:
First, sometimes the blessings are due to that realm;
Second, the people here are coarse and there are none who can receive the sÅ«tra;
Third, their merits are not yet complete;
Fourth, there are those who can expound the sÅ«tra in the world, so Maitreya does not descend.
In the future, after five billion seven hundred and sixty million years, the people of Maitreya's time will all see four thousand li with their eyes.
The reason why the people of Maitreya's time will see four thousand li with their eyes is because they have accomplished ten causes and conditions:
First, not covering up the brightness of others' eyes;
Second, not abandoning others' eyes;
Third, not obscuring others' eyes;
Fourth, not hiding others' good deeds;
Fifth, not looking at killing;
Sixth, not looking at stealing;
Seventh, not looking at sexual misconduct;
Eighth, not looking at others' secrets or shortcomings;
Ninth, not looking at evil things;
Tenth, lighting lamps in Buddhist temples;
These are the ten things.
The Buddha, pratyekabuddhas, and arhats - these three people have the same Dharma but different practices:
The Buddha is one who awakens to the truth;
Pratyekabuddhas understand through seeing causes and conditions;
Arhats know through sitting in meditation.

Pratyekabuddhas see the appearance of birth and death through causes and conditions, and they guard themselves, not daring to depart from practice. They attain the Way through seeing causes and conditions, and thus they become pratyekabuddhas.
The Buddha is one who practices the Way in order to liberate people, and thus he seeks to become a pratyekabuddha.

A pratyekabuddha once saved five hundred people by cutting his own body, and he saw causes and conditions by piercing his neck with wood. He calculated that cutting into the earth revealed blood as water, and seeing all things as impermanent, he then attained the Way.

There was a pratyekabuddha who in a past life was a bodhisattva for five hundred kalpas. His body already had thirty marks, lacking only two marks to become a buddha. The reason he did not become a buddha was because he lacked skillful means.

The Buddha spoke of the hardships of birth and death and the affairs of the three evil paths. A wise person understands and immediately attains arhatship. Although attaining arhatship, he is the most revered among them.
Why is this?

Because in his past lives he practiced the bodhisattva path for five hundred kalpas, with a compassionate mind wishing to liberate the people of the ten directions. Although he attained arhatship and wisdom, he could understand the languages of various regions.

When he first became an arhat, he could not yet realize his past lives as a bodhisattva. The Buddha then spoke of the Buddha's merits and also spoke of the merits of arhatship. Only then did he know that the Buddha's merits were great, and he regretted wanting to change his mind and attain Buddhahood.
The Buddha said:
Having already attained the path of arhatship, it cannot be attained again. He then regretted and said:
'How foolish was I to rightly attain the path of arhatship?
The Buddha then explained the meaning for him:
Your wisdom surpasses that of other arhats, but your wisdom is not equal to that of the Buddha.
An arhat ends their own suffering but does not end the suffering of others. The Buddha ends both his own suffering and the suffering of others, so they are not the same.
The Buddha said:
ÅšÄriputra!
There are three kinds of speech that can fully understand a person's thoughts:
First, coarse speech;
Second, profound speech;
Third, leading speech.
If one obtains these three kinds of speech, one can see good thoughts, see evil thoughts, see thoughts of endurance, and from these three kinds of speech, fully understand a person's thoughts.
ÅšÄriputra said to the Buddha:
In the time it takes to snap one's fingers, a person has sixty births and deaths?
The Buddha said:
There are nine hundred and sixty births and deaths, not many more, but there must be three kinds of thoughts:
There are good thoughts, evil thoughts, and desirous thoughts.

There are three hundred and twenty good thoughts, three hundred and twenty evil thoughts, and three hundred and twenty desirous thoughts. In the time it takes to snap one's fingers, these three thoughts arise together, adding up to nine hundred and sixty births and deaths.
Excluding the three hundred and twenty good thoughts, there are six hundred and forty thoughts of birth and death remaining.

The Buddha and ÅšÄriputra practiced the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment together, but their wisdom was not equal. It is like breathing, which comes and goes through all the pores. One who is aware can only know the breath coming in and out of the nose.ğŸ”½The Buddha knows everything, including all the pores. What ÅšÄriputra knows is like the nostrils. Take ÅšÄriputra's knowledge and divide it into sixteen parts. Fill a Buddha realm of a billion worlds with people as wise as ÅšÄriputra, and their knowledge does not equal one part of what ÅšÄriputra knows.

Take the Buddha's knowledge and divide it into sixteen parts. Fill a Buddha realm with people whose knowledge equals ÅšÄriputra's, and their knowledge does not equal one part of what the Buddha knows.
The thirty-seven factors of enlightenment are divided into three groups: the great thirty-seven factors, the medium thirty-seven factors, and the small thirty-seven factors.

Those with a great mind attain a great mind, those with a medium mind attain a medium mind, and those with a small mind attain a small mind. Those who deeply and wonderfully practice the thirty-seven factors will penetrate them.
Why is this?
The correct factors are divided into sixteen parts. Since people originally have sixteen intentions, the Buddha distinguishes them, and therefore they are not the same.
ÅšÄriputra knows the language of all dharmas. He uses timely language, protective language, and guarded language. The Buddha then said to ÅšÄriputra:
Go and abandon untimely language, because it cannot be entrusted to others.
ÅšÄriputra's original name was Upatiá¹£ya.
ÅšÄriputra!
There are three reasons why past Buddhas transcended the world:
First, because their past lives are exhausted;
Second, because they do not wish to see the Buddha transcending the world;
Third, because there is no one left to be liberated.
After ÅšÄriputra had received people's food, he returned to the monastery and said he would repay the debt:

It means that one should sit in meditation and contemplate the Way to repay the debt. Not contemplating the Way is to take on debt by accepting people's offerings. It is like taking on more debt before the previous one is paid off, and committing more offenses now before the previous ones are finished.
The Buddha said:
One who eats the offerings of others should not fail to contemplate the Way. One will also attain more benefits for oneself and all others. Therefore, one should repay the debt.
The Buddha said:
ÅšÄriputra is foremost in wisdom, MaudgalyÄyana is foremost in spiritual powers, Ä€nanda is foremost in hearing, RÄhula is foremost in precepts, and Aniruddha is foremost in clairvoyance.
The Buddha sent MaudgalyÄyana to invite ÅšÄriputra.
ÅšÄriputra said:
Lift my belt, I'm afraid it won't be able to bear it.
MaudgalyÄyana then pulled the belt, and the three thousand great one thousand worlds, the sun, moon, earth, and heavens all shook, but he could not make the belt rise.
ÅšÄriputra had the idea to go to the Buddha first, while MaudgalyÄyana would follow behind. ÅšÄriputra arrived first.
The Buddha knew that the two of them were each the best.
In the worlds of the ten directions, there is no bhiká¹£u who upholds the precepts like RÄhula.
RÄhula upholds the precepts for four reasons:
First, he thinks to himself:
'I am the Buddha's son.'

'I am a Å›ramaá¹‡a.'

ÅšÄriputra!

ÅšÄriputra was still able to do this, let alone the Buddha!

When King VesÄlÄ« reached the twelfth gate, he still did not know the six parts of his body. He held the intention to be able to practice the Way, but did not know whether the body gives rise to the mind or the mind gives rise to the body. He was unable to discern this.
The Buddha knew that he was to be saved, so he went to stay with him. The king did not know that he was the Buddha.
The Buddha asked:
'What Dharma do you practice, and what Way do you like?'
His hair stood on end.
The Buddha explained the emptiness of the body's affairs, and he then attained the Way.
He did not completely cut off [afflictions], and did not attain arhatship.
The Buddha said:
All practitioners should know that the mind can attain the Way.
The Buddha said:
In the past, Matali PÅ«rvatanaya studied the scriptures for twenty-four years and attained the five-line understanding of abandoning defilements, and he was also no longer worried.
Why is this?
In his previous lives, he had seen five hundred Buddhas and knew all the scriptures, but he kept the Way of the scriptures hidden and was unwilling to teach others.
Later, for twenty-four days, he was sick. When he was about to die, he repented and called out to others to teach them.
Because of this one merit, he knew five sentences. How much more so for those who fully teach others, whose merit and virtue are incalculable. Li Mantai (Zhu Li Pan Du).
The Buddha said:

ÅšÄriputra asked him:

Chan Na replied:

Even if the body dies, earth, water, fire, wind, and space will all cease, but only the consciousness will move and be reborn.'
The Buddha sent ÅšÄriputra to go on alms round, passing by a prostitute's house. The woman then closed the door and prepared the way, saying to ÅšÄriputra:

When the monks heard the Buddha speak these words, they were delighted, their minds were liberated, and they immediately attained arhatship.

He followed behind the Buddha sweeping away the Buddha's footprints, not letting people see the Buddha's marks, and also spoke among people that the Buddha had no path, only speaking words that accord with people's minds.
ÅšÄriputra and Ä€nanda heard this and became sorrowful and unhappy.

People in the world only consider slight suffering to be thick suffering.

The Buddha's disciples Aniruddha, Nanda, and Kimbila sat together and contemplated seven matters:
First, those with few desires attain the Way, those with many desires do not attain the Way;
Second, those who are content attain the Way, those who are not content do not attain the Way;
Third, those who are diligent attain the Way, those who are not diligent do not attain the Way;
Fourth, those who guard the six senses to prevent them from arising attain the Way, those who do not guard the six senses and let them arise do not attain the Way;

Fifth, those who protect themselves attain the Way, while those who do not protect themselves do not attain the Way;ğŸ”½Sixth, those who guard their minds attain the Way, while those who do not guard their minds do not attain the Way;

They discussed these seven matters together.
At that time, they were sixty li away from the Buddha.
The Buddha was sitting in meditation and immediately knew what the three people were thinking. He then shifted his mind and sat in front of the three people, saying:
Excellent! Excellent!
I will tell you one more thing:
Those who do not think of the desires of the household attain the Way, while those who think of the desires of the household do not attain the Way.
Thereupon, the three people rejoiced and immediately attained the stage of a bodhisattva.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
The eyes of a person can see up to 420,000 yojanas.
How do we know this?
The sun and moon are 420,000 yojanas away from the ground, and people's eyes can see the sun and moon. From this, we know what the eyes can see.
The vast and distant ten directions, the sun and moon are billions of times more numerous than the sands in the great ocean, which cannot be counted.
The good and evil deeds done by people, the blessings and misfortunes that follow, the blessings and misfortunes created in the past, are billions of times too numerous to count.

All good and evil are present at the time of the end of life. Doing evil leads to encountering evil places, doing good leads to obtaining good places. Blessings and misfortunes are all preordained, and there are all preordained places.
If one's parents, brothers, and wife and children attain the Way, it will cease. If they do not attain the Way, it will not cease.
The Buddha said:
Devadatta only teaches people to create blessings, not to practice the Way;
The Buddha teaches people to create blessings, keep precepts, guard the mind, and attain the Way, then it will cease.
Devadatta himself thought:
'I will display my supernormal powers before King Ajatashatru. If the king follows me, the others will also follow. I will then transform into a white elephant and enter and exit the palace alone.
He then transformed into a small child, incomparably handsome, and sat on the king's lap. The king loved him greatly.

Seeing what Devadatta had done, the king thought Devadatta was superior to the Buddha. The king then followed Devadatta's words. The king's officials, people, and the monks who had not yet attained the Way all followed the king to Devadatta to ask about matters.
Devadatta then went to the Buddha and said:
The Buddha is old and no longer needs to teach the disciples.
Devadatta then called for ÅšÄriputra and the other monks to leave.
Because of Devadatta's foolish greed and evil intentions, he lost his spiritual powers.
The Buddha said:
The foolish person's actions are upside down, not in accord with the Buddha's teachings.
Devadatta himself thought:
'I will fly away. Everyone who sees me flying will serve me.'
Because of this, he wanted to fly away but could not fly anymore.
When Devadatta was unable to regain his spiritual powers by himself, there was a wandering ascetic who practiced equanimity, who then came down from the first heaven and said to ÅšÄriputra:

The Buddha said to ÅšÄriputra:
Devadatta wants to summon you, and will incur grave offenses again.
The Buddha said to the deity:
Before Devadatta had attained spiritual powers, I knew he would lose them.
How much more so now?
The Buddha said:
People should not be greedy. Devadatta lost his spiritual powers precisely because of his greed.
The Buddha said:
Arhats are of two types:
The first are called Å›rÄvakas, who are concerned with attaining liberation for themselves and immediately wish to transcend the world;

The Buddha and the arhats together practiced the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment. It is like a lamp. The Buddha calculated and knew how many things there were, and knew their origins and ends, guarded them, and extinguished them;
Arhats do not consider the beginning and end, but directly extinguish it.
The Buddha compares it to following a tree from the root to the branches, distinguishing and knowing it;
The practice of arhats is like going from the branches to the root.
Those who go from the root to the branches consider the root to be empty;
Those who do not know emptiness cannot attain the Way.
The Buddha said:

Arhats have the five aggregates but are without the five aggregates. All that they have is manifested but they are not attached. They have form, sensation, perception, conception, and consciousness but are without birth and death.
The Buddha said:
Arhats have something to be silent about. There are three characteristics of attaining arhatship:
First, they no longer violate body, speech, and mind;
Second, the three poisons are extinguished;
Third, they do not seek fine clothing and food, but only eliminate thoughts of hunger and cold.
With these three causes and conditions, they can transform freely, their minds are not attached;
Because of their decline, they cannot be free. The Buddha said:
